newsitem.title: FINLAND: NOKIA SALE TO CUT UPM DEBT.
newsitem.headline: NOKIA SALE TO CUT UPM DEBT.

text.p: Finnish forestry group UPM-Kymmene said on Thursday it planned to use the proceeds of the sale of some Nokia shares to improve its balance sheet.

"This is to reduce debt which is well-known as our central target," Chief Financial Officer Jan-Henrik Kulp said by telephone after UPM said it would book a pre-tax capital gain of 1.5 billion markka on the sale of 4.5 million Nokia shares.

But Kulp added the company did not earmark funds for any specific use. He declined to specify the price or price range of the transaction, which he said was carried out privately with brokerage Goldman Sachs.

Kulp said the transaction was carried out in one day on Wednesday, and repeated that there had been "no decision to sell" on Tuesday evening, when rumours the company had sold or was selling its Nokia stake resurfaced.
Asked if UPM would sell more Nokia shares soon or this year, Kulp said: "We are not considering selling now."
UP said in a statement on Wednesday evening that Goldman Sachs would reoffer the Nokia shares globally, and the deal still left it with 7.1 million Nokia shares.
